content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

The three stable isotopes of <math alttext="M g " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="M g 24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg-24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M g 25" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg-25</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="M g 26" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg-26</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. A rock sample from another planet has a different distribution of the three stable isotopes than what is found on Earth. A partial mass spectrum for <math alttext="M g " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the rock sample is shown below.

(a) Draw a line on the graph to show the mass of the missing isotope and its percent abundance.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

The three stable isotopes of <math alttext="M g " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="M g 24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg-24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="M g 25" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg-25</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="M g 26" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg-26</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. A rock sample from another planet has a different distribution of the three stable isotopes than what is found on Earth. A partial mass spectrum for <math alttext="M g " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the rock sample is shown below.

(a) Draw a line on the graph to show the mass of the missing isotope and its percent abundance.

(b) Use the completed mass spectrum to calculate the average atomic mass of <math alttext="M g " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the other planet.

(c) The first ionization energy of magnesium samples found on Earth is experimentally determined to be <math alttext="736 kilojoules per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>736</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If a similar experiment is conducted to determine the first ionization energy of magnesium in the rock sample from another planet, will it be greater than, less than, or equal to the first ionization energy of magnesium found on Earth? Explain your reasoning.

(d) A table of successive ionization energies for <math alttext="M g " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and an unknown element is shown above. Predict the identity of the unknown element.

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
